author: andrea_nicolotti
post: Again: Hugh said: “I do not know if our information is contemporary, or if the first known information comes from a copy of a copy of a copy many years later. Does anybody else?” In order of time, the essential sources are: 1) Francesco Adorno (1578) 2) Filiberto Pingone (1581) 3) Giovanni Tonso (1596) 4) Giuseppe Cambiano di Ruffia (1606) 5) François Capré (1662) Only Pingone says to have been present during the fire. On 1532, he was eight years old. We have not other reliable testimonies. Obviously, Pingone’s history is highly exaggerated (miracles, enormous fire, rescuers of the shrine protected by a divine rain, etc.). Hugh said: “For two years the shroud disappears, and then requires the testimony of three bishops and ten noblemen to establish that the one which has mysteriously reappeared is the same one as disappeared two years previously. I wonder why. Wasn’t it obvious? Or were there dark suspicions that the original may in fact have been destroyed?” Some people said that the Shroud was destroyed by the fire: François Rabelais (1534), Antoine Froment (1534), Calvinus (1543), Michel Roset (1560 circa) Hugh said: “….Le Saint Suaire de Chambéry a Sainte Claire en Ville (Avril Mai 1534)”, which was published in 1891 by Abbé Léon Bouchage.” It is only the edition of the text you can find, in a better edition, in the Chevalier’s 1903 book (doc. P). If you write to me a personal email (andrea DOT nicolotti AT unito DOT it) I can send you this text, or both..
